awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Causation in Dynamical Systems: Bridging the Gap Between Data Analytics and System Identification
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project explores an innovative approach to system identification. System identification is the process of building a model for a physical system from observed experimental data.  System ID processes are used in a wide variety of scientific and engineering applications from weather prediction to aircraft design.  While numerous system ID algorithms have been developed to date, many current methods yield poorly performing models when applied to complicated physical systems involving numerous interacting components.  However, recent advancements in data analytics have yielded new algorithms that can identify patterns, and specifically causal relationships, in data.  This award supports fundamental research exploring how these new data analysis tools can inform the system ID process and enable a new class of system ID algorithms specifically applicable to large-scale, complex systems.  The resulting algorithms may be useful in difficult modeling and prediction problems including atmospheric/climate prediction, modeling of biological systems, or financial market analysis.  The approaches developed here may lead to better predictive models for many of these complex systems.  The program has strong ties to engineering education since undergraduates will have the opportunity to participate in specific experimental aspects of the research.

Despite extensive research in system identification over the past several decades, system ID tools for nonlinear or high-order systems are rather underdeveloped and oftentimes suffer from convergence or computational issues.  The research to be performed here leverages very recent advances in the mathematics and data analytics communities to derive a fundamentally novel approach to system identification based on information theory.  At the core of this research is the concept of causation entropy, an entropic measure of information transfer within a dynamical system that can be computed directly from measured output data.  The project seeks to derive rigorous, causation entropy-based approaches for nonlinear parameter estimation and model order reduction, as well as establish a fundamental realization theory for linear Gaussian systems using causation entropy.  Furthermore, the problem of identifying input-output dynamics will be addressed from an information theory perspective.  A series of case studies will be generated which highlight performance and utility of the system identification methods in a wide range of real-world examples.

por.por_cntn:
The world is full of systems and phenomena whose behavior is extremely difficult to model. In some cases, the difficulty in modeling a changing system of interest is due to the number of interacting elements involved - for instance, infectious disease modeling or modeling of free-market economies.  In other cases, challenges in accurate modeling or prediction are caused by our lack of understanding of the underlying physics involved - this is often the case in biological systems or astrophysics, for example.  The science and engineering communities have developed techniques to model and predict the behavior of such systems through a process known as black-box or grey-box modeling.  These techniques involve the collection of data from a system of interest, followed by fitting of a mathematical model.  This empirical model fitting process is used extensively in the machine learning community and has been revolutionized by the widespread use of neural networks and other advanced regression methods.


A key step in the process of model fitting involves the selection of a category or candidate set of model components, from which the model will be constructed.  This process is known as covariate selection.  An initial set of model covariates or components is first selected, and then data is used to identify which covariates should be retained and which covariates are extraneous.  This process is critical in achieving a model that accurately predicts future behavior of the system - elimination of too many covariates results in a model that cannot adequately describe the system's behavior.  Retention of too many covariates leads to the problem of "overfitting" in which the model accurately matches previous data but does a poor job in predicting future behavior.


Several techniques have been developed to perform covariate selection.  These techniques, such as the elastic net algorithm and the Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Algorithm (LASSO), seek to identify parameters in the system model and simultaneously determine which covariates to retain.  These methods are highly sensitive to tuning and do not provide a straightforward answer regarding which covariates are necessary to achieve accuracy with respect to both historical and future data.  


This NSF grant supported the development of a new covariate selection technique based on a mathematical quantity called causation entropy.  Causation entropy measures the influence between a candidate covariate and the dynamics of a state of the system.  By computing the causation entropy between each of the candidate covariates and each state of the system, the necessary covariates that should be retained in the model can be identified.  The attached Fig. 1 shows a visualization of this process for an example system.  The figure shows a matrix where each row and column map to a state of the system and a candidate covariate, respectively.  The left matrix shows grayscale values where the intensity represents the magnitude of the underlying system parameter (which would be unknown in an actual problem).  The right side of the figure shows the estimated causation entropy values corresponding to each covariate-state interaction, computed solely from recorded measurements of the system.  The matrix on the right has the same structure as the actual parameter matrix, meaning the necessary covariates that must be retained in the model, and their degree of influence on the dynamics of each state, can be immediately identified.  This would allow the system modeler to significantly reduce the number of parameters that must be estimated, leading to a more accurate model that is less susceptible to overfitting.  An initial journal paper was published documenting this new technique in 2018.


Additional work was performed investigating the robustness of this new covariate selection approach and developing test cases.  Research effort was focused on examining the sensitivity of the method to noise and sampling rate of the experimental data.  Results showed that higher noise and lower sampling rate degrade performance as expected, but noise effects can be mitigated using standard filtering techniques.  These results were the subject of a journal paper published in 2021.  Additional work compared performance of the causation entropy approach to other methods, namely LASSO and elastic net.  Results showed that in many cases, causation entropy provides more accurate covariate selection than these two methods (see Fig. 2) while removing the need for tuning of algorithm parameters.  These results were presented at the American Control Conference in 2021.  Finally, a case study was developed showing successful application of the causation entropy technique to data gathered from an experimental device, illustrating successful use of the method with real-world data.  These results were published in a journal article in 2022.  The causation entropy method developed during this grant was implemented in open-source software and is now available freely for use by the scientific and engineering communities via Github.
